description.text:
This is the Relic Claw designed by FIRST Tech Challenge team 9794 Wizards.exe. It is mostly 3D-printed, but it does utilize other parts. The WITHOUTNUMBERS parts have the 9794 embossings removed.

Materials Needed

  • 1 Bracket.stl or BracketWITHOUTNUMBERS.stl (3d printed)
  • 1 RotatingPart.stl or RotatingpartWITHOUTNUMBERS.stl (3d printed)
  • 1 Linkage.stl (3d printed)
  • 2 Actobotics 535198 (Flanged 1/2" OD 1/4" ID bearing)
  • 2 Actobotics 633104 (1/4" Shaft Spacer)
  • A standard size servo (The 2 servos we have used are the Rev smart robot servo and the Hitec 485HB)
  • Actobotics 575124 (Standard Servo Plate B)
  • Actobotics 525116 or other compatible servo horn (Read Note) Note: This servo horn will work for anything with a 24T spline. A much cheaper alternative to this is to take one of the servo horns that come with the servo and drill a hole approx 1 inch from the center.
  • 1 1/4" shaft (Min length - 2.25") Note: Any 1/4" shaft will work. The one included is 2.5" long. Actobotics part 634070 works just fine.


There are 4 mounting holes on the bracket.stl part. On our robot we have those connected to an Actobotics ServoBlock which is connected to the robot, but mounting is up to you.
To assemble you press the bearings into the holes on RotatingPart.stl with the flanges on the inside. Then, you take your shaft and put it through, placing the shaft spacers between the bearings and the bracket.stl part. After that, put the horn on the servo so that the limits are parallel to the servo's long side. Screw in the servo and the servo mount. Finally, screw in the linkage.stl part.
If you use this claw, please send us an email at [email protected] telling us and attribute the claw to us.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Finally finished up the small canopy shape for the Stratosurfer. There are two versions, one with a bolt on deck feature that fits my Pan and Tilts found on my Wiki here:

http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Parts_Catalog_-_Pan_and_Tilt_Parts

The second option is simply a plain canopy that you can carve up to fit your needs.

Both have a bevelled edge, copied from the original foam cover, which helps them fit nice and snug into the foam base. They have ventilation ports that can also be used for headlights. There is a mount piece which screws down to the plywood deck and is tapped to M3 for the hold-down screws.

For more information on my Stratosurfer build, please see my build page here:

http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Strix_StratoSurfer

Print Notes:
The canopy is designed to be printed right-side-up, as it sits on the plane.
The canopy shown in the pictures was printed in ABS at .2mm quality.

Please consider leaving a tip or donating via paypal on my website: http://ferociousdesigns.co.uk/ if you like this design! All support is very much appreciated!

Update 10/02/18: Updated both main body and arm to v2. Moved filament hole down 0.5mm to make loading easier as it was hitting the bearing.

This is a further iteration from my 'Simple Bowden Exruder' based on the Anet A8 stock extruder design but optimised for TPU. It requires more parts than the previous iteration, however should perform even better!

Features:

  • Small Size: Only 2mm deeper than the standard Anet A8 extruder when used as a bowden.
  • Compatibility: Mounts to any bowden mount that can take a Nema 17 Stepper
    Works with flexible filament as well as PLA / ABS etc
    Works with various extruder gears from 12 - 14mm diameter
  • Near 100% supported filament path
  • PC4M6 In / Out: Prevents grinding on the edge of the arm, and provides more support for the filament to make loading easier.

Printing:
I have tried to orient the parts into the best position for printing, however you are free to print how you want to of course :) I use 10% line supports on everything in Cura as they are very easy to remove. Printed with 25% infill using Anet PLA. During cleanup, bore the filament hole out to 2mm if it is not already.

Required parts:
3x M3x17mm Bolts to mount to bowden mount and stepper
1x M3x12mm Cap head bolt for arm retainer
1x M3x20mm Cap head bolt for spring adjuster
5x M3 Washers (Arm Hinge x3, spring adjuster x2)
4x M3 Nuts (Arm retainer, arm bolt, spring adjuster x2)
4x F623zz bearings (arm hinge x2, spring adjuster x2)
1x 625 bearing (filament idler)
1x Spring 8mm wide x 20mm long
1x MK7 Extruder Gear (Other gears may work but not tested)

Building:

Assemble the arm first and then bolt it to the main body piece. Wind the tensioner out all the way to make it easier to mount.

The arm hinge should go: Washer between bearing on the arm and the front plate, bearing, bearing, washer, m3 nut, washer. Then attach to bowden mount / stepper.

The spring tensioner on the arm should be: M3 bolt with nut tightend all the way up to its head (this should push fit into the 'Extuder button' piece), washer, bearing, bearing, washer, M3 nut, Spring retainer with embedded M3 nut facing the arm.

To set the extruder gear into the right position on the shaft, you can attach the built arm without the front plate.

Notes:

I uploaded file with manually drawn support. I was able to easly temove them after printing using scalpel.
Manually drawn supports improve printing speed over slicer generated, because printing full loop is faster than printing half loop and slowing-ozzing-retracting, restarting to print over each gap where support is in between.

All the corners are heavily cussioned. After using this case for 3 months I can assure that it has been tested on rought impacts with concrete floor and the phone DOES bounce off from the floor.

Printed with TPU based Flexy Fit fillament.
I chose mine to make fully custom by postprocessing case with soldering iron. Even most expesive heavy duty cases cannot stand against how grippy and protected from impacts my phone feels now.
Drone

Designed in Fusion 360...quite pleased indeed :)
You will need to flip the design in your slicer so you can see the recessed bolt holes and the washer/spacers are level on the bed :)
Uses 22mm skateboard/fidget spinner bearings, 8mm nuts and bolts (found in the garage).
I did revise the file for slightly larger holes and washers as they were a bit tight so these should be spot on. :) PLA 190c bed 60c...I did start bed at 70 for the first layer but think it was a bit warm.
PS preview shows the bottom! odd but the other side shows the recessed holes for the nuts and bolts.

print_settings.Notes:: The connections between the "shaft" and the truss are very tight. The group design it like this so the bridge would not rotate when loaded. You many need to use a rubber mallet to assemble the bridge correctly or else you can scale down the "shaft" to allow a looser fit.

description.text:
Experiment Description
For this experiment, the students in the lab were required to design a truss or bridge to span a specific distance and resist a 100 lb load in a four point flexure test. All the requirements for the bridge are shown below:
• Span length of 400 mm
• Width of 75 mm
• Maximum height of 75 mm
• Maximum weight 100 grams
• Must hold 45 kg (100 lbs)
• No adhesion (glue, etc..) for connections

The challenge for the student in this experiment was their bridge had to be printed in separate parts because the bridges were to large to print all at once. The students had to design connections for these parts without the use of glue or other adhesives. The connection design was critical because that is the weakest points on their trusses.

Information on Group 2’s Bridge:
This is the design from Group 2 in the laboratory. Their truss design is commonly known as a Howe Truss. This group kept their design simple with a total of 3 parts. They designed their lateral connection (the “shaft” file) to hold the truss together to resist the normal and shear forces acting along the connections and to resist overturning laterally. The bridge had a total weight of 96 grams and resisted a load of 140 lbs. Note due to the high loading, the group did not load the bridge to failure, so I can not report the failure mechanism.

Note:
The handout for this experiment will be available soon. I will provide a link to the handout in this description when it is complete, so you can perform this experiment yourself or with your students.

Notes:

The connections between the "shaft" and the truss are very tight. The group design it like this so the bridge would not rotate when loaded. You many need to use a rubber mallet to assemble the bridge correctly or else you can scale down the "shaft" to allow a looser fit.
Figure 1. This is the bridge being tested in a four point flexure test Figure 2. Stress analysis of group 2's truss. Blue means the member is in compression and red means the member is in tension

title: ISDT Discharger parallel board with 6 XT60 Ports

description.text:
Parallel Board for ISDT Discharger with 6 XT60 Ports. To discharge multiple LiPo batteries at the same time when the weather or plans change.

I got two ISDT dischargers to discharge multiple batches of batteries at once.

Solder all connectors with two exposed copper wires which in turn solder to main connector.
Do not have to insulate anything because it will be on the inside of enclosure. Make sure the wire can handle 6 amps, which can be pretty thin diameter. When connections are made, you can seal enclosure permanently with CA glue or use small screws, utilizing mounting holes.

XT60 connectors when inserted and lined up secure with CA glue from the inside. My print doesn't look so pretty because I used CA glue on the outside and then tried to paint it with black primer, also I recycled old XT60 connectors from other projects.

Have fun printing ... don't forget to like if you find it useful.

title: FTC Relic Claw - Universal build kit compatibility

description.text:
This is a relic claw that is molded around the relic. If you want to use with a build system that isn't Rev, you'll have to make your own adapter piece. It's a small piece, and is relatively easy to design and print.

We based the design off a claw we saw here on thingiverse, but we made some notably different decisions in design. We wanted to have a claw that printed flat, and that wouldn't break. We couldn't guarantee that it wouldn't break, so we made a piece that connects the claw to your mounting hardware that takes all the force and will the piece to break. This means instead of having to reprint your whole claw, you'll only have to print off a small piece. This also allows teams that don't use the Rev extrusion system to modify the adapter piece to their hardware specs.

The servo mount does use super glue to be held in place, but we've had a claw put together for three months and it hasn't broken (that was a different version, without the adapter piece).

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Infill:

Glue in the servo holder

When you have both the relic mold and the servo holder printed out, you can glue them together. I recommend using a quick set glue, or using small clamps to hold it together.

Make sure to coat the two main surfaces that'll be touching with glue, the channel that the rib of the servo holder fits in, and all the seams.

UPDATE
I have printed this and the repaired model slices great in Simplify3D as well as Cura: https://www.thingiverse.com/make:444835

Also, a big thanks to davwilso and his original design for Gain jugs: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2748680

No

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I sliced this in Simplify3D and you really have to be careful about how you do the supports. See the model photos above to see how I laid out mine. You especially don't want any supports within the body cavity where the detergent will drain through.

https://youtu.be/OHdih0OKZts

After it's printed, there's a good deal of support removal necessary, especially around the threads. I'm not sure I got all of it out because it's probably not possible to remove some of the inner-most support under the threads.

But needless to say, it still broke free and spun enough to install, so I'm totally fine with that. If you decide to print this without supports around the threads, please post a comment about your experience, very interested if that works or not.

title: Manipulateur télégraphique du 19ième siècle – Activité éducative
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Le télégraphe est l’un des premiers appareils de communication à avoir tiré parti de la puissance de l’électricité. Il a révolutionné les communications sur de longues distances. Le manipulateur télégraphique en constituait un élément essentiel. Cette activité consiste à construire un manipulateur télégraphique. Elle va permettre aux élèves d’acquérir des notions de base sur les circuit simple et la conductivité.

Objectifs d'apprentissage
Cette activité permettra aux élèves de :
i) Apprendre comment construire un circuit simple doté d’un interrupteur;
ii) Apprendre des notions de base sur la conductivité.

Informations supplémentaires
Les premières communications sur de longues distances consistaient essentiellement à transmettre des codes et des symboles au moyen d’indicateurs visuels, comme des signaux de fumée. Cette méthode avait notamment comme inconvénient de nécessiter une visibilité directe, qui pouvait être entravée par le mauvais temps ou par des obstacles naturels ou artificiels, entre autres.

Le manipulateur télégraphique est la partie d’un télégraphe électrique qui sert à transmettre les messages. Il en existe de nombreux modèles. Celui qui est illustré ici est dit « à dos de chameau » en raison de l’aspect du levier. Il est fait de laiton et a été utilisé dans un bureau télégraphique de Metcalfe (Ontario), qui a été ouvert de 1870 à 1912.

Remarque : L’image 3D complète de l’artefact porte le nom « manipulateur télégraphique.stl ». Il est conçu pour être visualisé dans un environnement virtuel au moyen d’un logiciel. Vous pouvez tenter de l’imprimer. Toutefois, nous ne pouvons garantir la qualité de l’impression. Pour fabriquer votre propre manipulateur télégraphique, téléchargez le fichier « manipulateur télégraphique - pièces.zip » et suivez les instructions ci-dessous.

Vous trouverez nos conditions d’utilisation à l’adresse https://ingeniumcanada.org/ingenium/doc/content/cstmc/CSTMC%20terms%20of%20use%203D%20FR.pdf

Vous trouverez les autres activités sur les manipulateur télégraphiques à l’adresse
https://ingeniumcanada.org/ingenium/musees/educatif/manipulateur-telegraphique-3D.php

Assemblage des parties du manipulateur télégraphique

Dans cette activité, les vis et les disques composant l’appareil seront désignés par les lettres figurant dans l’Image 1 dans la visionneuse d'images principale (en haut de la page).

Construction de la base
1) Avec la vis A, fixez la poignée courbée à la base en forme de O du manipulateur télégraphique. Assurez-vous que la courbe est dirigée vers le centre de la base (Image 2 dans la visionneuse d'images principale).

2) Mettez les disques C et D sur leurs vis respectives. Fixez chacun des ensembles disque-vis sur un côté de la base (Image 3a et 3b dans la visionneuse d'images principale).

Fabrication du levier
Mettez le disque B sur la vis B. Fixez l’ensemble disque-vis sur le levier du manipulateur télégraphique (Image 4 dans la visionneuse d'images principale).

Fonctionnement du manipulateur télégraphique
Il est maintenant temps d’ajouter au manipulateur télégraphique les accessoires qui le rendront fonctionnel.

1) Courbez l’extrémité de la branche la plus longue de chacune des deux attaches en laiton pour créer un petit taquet (Image 5 dans la visionneuse d'images principale).

2) Collez l’une des attaches en laiton au marteau du levier (Image 6 dans la visionneuse d'images principale). Collez l’autre attache en laiton à l’enclume de la base (Image 7 dans la visionneuse d'images principale). Dans chaque cas, séparez les branches de l’attache en laiton pour qu’elles restent de chaque côté de l’objet auquel elles sont collées.

3) Fixez le levier à la base en insérant les parties pointues du levier dans les vis C et D (qui ont déjà été fixées à la base).

4) Mettez l’élastique autour du levier et de la base à l’extrémité opposée à celle des attaches en laiton. L’élastique permettra au manipulateur télégraphique de revenir vers le haut lorsqu’il sera utilisé (Image 8 dans la visionneuse d'images principale).

5) Fixez une pince crocodile au taquet de chacune des attaches en laiton.

6) Fixez l’autre extrémité de l’un des fils avec pinces crocodile utilisés à l’étape 5 au fil positif du porte pile (de couleur rouge, habituellement). Fixez l’autre extrémité de l’autre fil avec pinces crocodile utilisé à l’étape 5 à la borne positive de la DEL ou de l’avertisseur (dans le cas d’une DEL, c’est le fil le plus long).

7) Utilisez un troisième fil avec pinces crocodile pour relier la borne négative de la DEL ou de l’avertisseur au fil négatif du porte pile (de couleur noire, habituellement).

8) Fixez la pile de 9 V au porte-pile (Image 9 dans la visionneuse d'images principale).

9) Facultatif : Si vous utilisez une DEL, le fait de tenir longtemps le manipulateur télégraphique en position basse peut la surchauffer et la brûler. Pour éviter cette situation, ajoutez une résistance au circuit. Dans le cas d’une pile de 9 V, une résistance de 200 à 300 Ω devrait suffire (voir l’étape 10 pour effectuer un calcul facultatif). Vous aurez également besoin d’un fil isolé avec pinces crocodile (le « 4e fil »). Pour ajouter une résistance :

a) Déterminez le fil avec pinces crocodile qui est relié au fil positif de la pile.
b) Libérez l’une des pinces crocodile de ce fil et la fixez
c) Fixez cette pince crocodile à l’une des extrémités de la résistance.
d) Fixez l’autre extrémité de la résistance à l’une des pinces crocodile du 4e fil.
e) Fixez l’autre pince crocodile du 4e fil à l’endroit laissé libre à l’étape b.
(Image 10 dans la visionneuse d'images principale)

10) Facultatif : Pour déterminer la résistance que la DEL requiert, utilisez les équations ci-dessous :

a) Tension (en V) = tension de la pile (en V) – tension de la DEL (en V)
b) Résistance requise (en Ω) = tension (en V) ÷ intensité maximale de la DEL (en A)

La tension et l’intensité maximales d’une DEL sont généralement indiquées sur l’emballage.

11) Le manipulateur télégraphique est maintenant prêt à utiliser ! Essentiellement, le télégraphe est un circuit simple qui, lorsqu’il est fermé, assure la transmission d’un signal. Dans cette activité, lorsqu’on appuie sur le manipulateur télégraphique (qui fonctionne comme un interrupteur), les deux attaches en laiton se touchent, ce qui ferme le circuit et déclenche l’avertisseur ou allume l’ampoule.

Exercice
Pour réaliser une étude plus approfondie de la conductivité, demandez aux élèves de
prédire ce qui arriverait si d’autres matériaux étaient intégrés au circuit télégraphique,
p. ex. du papier, un bout de ficelle et une pièce de monnaie. Ensuite, intégrez ces matériaux
au circuit au moyen d’un quatrième fil isolé et de pinces crocodile.

1 - pile de 9 V^
1 - porte-pile de 9 V^
1 - pistolet à colle
1 - version imprimée des parties du manipulateur télégraphique
4 - fils isolés avec pinces crocodile
1 - élastique
2 - attaches en laiton
1 - avertisseur électrique ou diode électroluminescente (DEL)^^
1 - résistance de 200 à 300 Ω (facultatif)

^ Remarque : Vous pouvez utiliser une pile différente (pile AA, p. ex.) avec porte-pile approprié.
^^ Remarque : Vous pouvez utiliser tout dispositif qui indique la présence d’un courant électrique. Peu importe ce dispositif, assurez-vous qu’il peut supporter la tension de la pile.

title: CR-10 Frame Stiffener Brace (5/16" Allthread) USA

description.text:
Modeled for my Creality CR-10S, 300x300x400.
Most frame stiffener brace kits that I see use 8mm all-thread or specialty tube and glue in inserts. I live in a small town in USA and nobody stocks metric all-thread. So I developed this kit using 5/16-18 unc all-thread. Also you will notice that I hide both hex nuts inside the printed parts for a cleaner look. The only consideration you need while assembling each side is if your just a faction off with your rod length, you will need to remove of of the hidden nuts and rotate it 1/6 of a turn. this will let you turn the perfect length of hitting the slots in the extruded rails perfectly. Well to 1/6th of a rotation.

The parts you need are:
(2) Upper Frame Brace (printed)
(2) Lower Frame Brace (printed)
(2) 5/16-18 unc all-thread x 24"
(8) 5/16-18 unc hex nuts (1/2" across flats)
(4) M3 x 20mm long socket head screws
(12) M3 x 10mm long socket head screws
(16) M3 hex nuts
(16) M3 hammer head nuts for 2020 aluminum extrusion.

You can print hammer head nuts using this file:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2469130

I didn't have any 3M x 10mm long socket head screws, but i did have 12mm ones. and i modeled the flats up just enough for the head clearance and washers would not fit for spacers. So I printed out some quick 2mm spacers so the screws would not bottom out. lesson learned - count and measure your screws before you CAD up some models and print them.

This kit does slightly reduce max printing height.
Edit: It reduced my total height by 7mm. it also reduced my total width by 10mm when the gantry is over 310mm on the Z axis. I never print large max dimension boxes, so its not an issue for me.

I also ended up wrapping the All-thread in black electrical tape to give it a cleaner appearance.

description.text:
For real Linux fans - Tux cookie cutter :)

Recipe:

  • 1/2 glass of sugar
  • 1 butter (200g)
  • about 3 glasses of wheat flour
  • vanilla flavor
  • flat spoon of baking soda
  • two yolks (but you can use whole eggs)

Mix everything, put in to the fridge (or freezer) in plastic bag until it gets stiff. Make it flat (about 3mm thick) and cut out cookies!

Bake in around 170C for about 15min. (look more for light golden colour than stick to this 15 minutes).

Enjoy!

title: MyRCCar F/R Differential Housing for HSP 02024 Diff. with adjustable caster

description.text:
Hi againz!

This would be the second chapter if you are planning to make your own MyRCCar.

I made this housing for the HSP 02024 FR diff or similar becouse i think is one of the easiest to find in the market and also with very cheap chinnesse compatible ones. I think most 1/10 4x4 kits include this kind of differential, at least cheap ones. As maybe you observed, i took mine from a Quanum Vandal kit, now discontinued... :( I paid 55€ for the kit and got many many parts from it... including FR diffs, shocks or wheels, links and screws.

For me, the interesting characteristic about this housing is that it allows you to change the caster of the axle just printing and changing 3 little parts, instead of rotating the whole housing or changing the chassis.

Obviously this diff housing has been designed to be used with MyRCCar Universal Chassis.

About bearings... I think you should be able to build the car only with 10x15x4 and 5x10x4 bearings. The question is how much of each. If you use CVDs and wheel vases wich uses two 5x10x4 as me you will need 8 of those for wheels. You will also need four 10x15x4 bearings, 2 for each differential, and 2 more if you want to use a 02024 as central differential. Remember, if you buy the differentials with bearings you can erase this last 6 ones. You will also need 4 small bearings for the steering towers. They could be 5x10x4 too...

And finally, you will need 4 more bearings to hold the pinions of the FR diffs. This can be 5x10x4 or 10x15x4. Just select the apropriate MRCC_FRD_BOTTOM.

As maybe you will know, i'm using 3d printed motor pinions now and they work great. So i decided to give it a try to a 3d printed pinion for the HSP 02024 differential. This pinion would be a HSP02030 replacement.
To do this pinion you will also need a 5mm piano wire of about 30mm long and a dremmel to cut it and to make a D-shape in one of the sides.sanding it.

Something similar happened with the vase of the differential. My Vandal kit only had 1 of this so i had to buy another or make it... And i made :) And they work :)

You can find both pinion and vase in version 5104 and 10154. Select the apropriate one to your MRCC_FRD_BOTTOM. Also you can select between M3 and M4 grubs screws for the Vases.

And the butterfly... will allow you to mount 80-100 mm big bore shocks in a buggy/truggy style rc car. If there is the need to modify it to make any other version it's easy.

So that's all by now! I hope i see you in the next chapter, the central diff housing... sounds boring?¿? There will be some surprises i hope you'll like!

If you have any question about this particular part please leave a coment here or in the related MyRCCar Group

print_settings.Notes:: For the Barrel Top & Bottom as well as Ratchet Tooth - make as strong as possible - high infill and 6+ walls.

description.text:
You will need a single print of all parts, except for the Handle (Choose small or large) and the Ratchet tooth (You need to print 2)
Inspired by seeing Cleven’s Pocket Ratchet Wrench https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:455507 , I decided to see if I could design a regular sized Ratcheting Socket Wrench which would be strong enough to be used for real world applications. The main body is split into a top and bottom section with a handle attached to the bottom section, which will be an interchangeable small or large handle (with different lengths to give better leverage)

The Design is fully 3D printed, with eight M4 machine screws fastening it together. The ratchet mechanism has attachments on each side, which was inspired by Cleven’s design to allow the ratchet to drive both clockwise and counter-clockwise.

The initial design allows the use of 12.5MM (1/2″) sized sockets, although the next development will be to allow the head to be interchanged with a head which can use 10MM (3/8″) sized sockets as well as standard 1/4″ hex tool bits.

title: Yet Another Creality New Super Fan Blower V5

description.text:
A simple mod printed in twenty minutes, installed in less than 3, that will double your stock Creality CR-10 bridging capacity... Why not?

This was designed to avoid interferring with your print, but please check that once installed the clearance between your aligned plate and the bottom line of YACNSFB is at least one millimeter.

I liked the idea of the original 3rDirective mod but :

  • I had to wait for longer screws to be delivered to test it...
  • I thought it would be better to redirect the air flow towards the extrusion point zone, not on the nozzle.
  • I needed to get in touch with Freecad. This is the fifth version obtained during a rainy sunday afternoon.

I've tested it in comparison with stock blower, using this test (see pictures):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1570562

The bridging capacity I evaluate would be at least 45 mm with this new design (bridge is not perfect, but the extruded wires are pretty well stuck together when bending with my finger).

With the stock blower part : 22.5mm bridge is already "messed up".

So I say : "this little piece of crap doubles (at least) your bridging capacity", since I used:

  • the same gcode ;
  • the same PLA wire ;
  • within the same hour and no print in between ;

for both test...

I did not test the original design by 3rDirective: it should also improve results but requires new screws... Mine does not!

Enjoy.

And many thanks to 3rDirective for its original idea.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Don't go too fast, and DO NOT forget to align the bottom plan of the STL with the plate. ("Lay flat" in Cura). The print should be easy.
After printed, just use the Hex key that is the size just one size bigger than the one you used to unmount the blower screws to adjust the fixing holes if some bad printing did occur.

Well that's it.

No further modification required to install this little thing.

title: Locking Tablet Mount for DJI Mavic Pro Controller
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This tablet mount fits into the contours and cutouts of the DJI Mavic Pro Controller to create a positive lock. This lock holds the tablet mount securely in place without relying on the controller's rubber grips.

Rather than using a claw or clamp to hold the tablet, this mount relies on the tablet case for a custom and secure hold. The tablet case is attached to this mount with 3M Command Strips. This provides a strong hold that is customized for any type, size, and brand of tablet.

Additional Parts:
• 2x GoPro long thumbscrews with nuts
• 2x Large 3M Command Strips
• 2x Medium 3M Command Strips
• Fitted Tablet Case (TPU Silicone and other smooth plastics work best with 3M Command Strips)

Assembly Steps:
• Print Tablet Plate and Remote Plate with at least 30% in-fill. No support required.
• Attach the Remote Plate to the Tablet Plate using GoPro long thumbscrews
• Apply Large Command Strips to the long edges of tablet plate
• Apply Medium Command Strips to the short edges of tablet plate
• Align the Tablet Plate with the Tablet using 2 perpendicular surfaces like a table and a wall
• Apply the Command Strips already on the Tablet Plate to the Tablet Case

Deployment Steps:
• Hold DJI Mavic Pro Controller in one hand.
• Slide the Tablet Mount into the controller's grip.
• Push the grips inward until you feel a "click"
• Connect USB cable
• Tighten the thumbscrews to "firm", but not too tight.
• Hold controller with the tablet rested on your forearms

In Progress:
The Tablet Plate was designed with 2 bars on the top side for attaching a glare shield. This will be an addition to this design in the near future.

author: timbologist

description.text: This is a parametric printable ankle board / balance board, which only allows motion in one axis. It is used to rehab ankle injuries, improve balance and agility, core strength, improve athletic coordination, increase ankle motion, and general jedi training. This component is part of an open source lab library, by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

Ankle boards range from $20 to over $100 for the really good ones that allow you to customize the size. This design not only does everything that the commercial versions do but is better than all of those as it allows you to alter the size of the half-cylinder in OpenSCAD so as you get better you can increase the difficulty by printing out a new piece. The OpenSCAD files is included so you can change the size and thus the difficulty of the board. The images show the default setting and STL.
  • Print the STL with a reasonable infill (e.g. this one was with 2 exterior layers and only 25% and it works fine - but the more support you give it the longer it should last) on your favorite open-source 3D printer.
  • Cut out a circle in plywood -- the easiest way to do this is to put a nail in the middle and then tie a string to your jigsaw the length equal to the radius of your wanted ankle board circle. Commercial versions of ankle or wobble boards are usually around 16 inches in diameter. This one was larger - if I were to make another one I would use thicker plywood.
  • Drill a hole in the middle of the circle
  • Bolt the printed hemisphere to the board with a 3/8 hex nut/bolt. The hemisphere has a hexnut hole in it meant to lock the nut in so you can tighten from the top and easily switch out hemispheres. This actually worked really well -- you can tighten the bolt down by turning the printed hemisphere.
    • Have fun!

description.text:
To AVA, from Uncle Les.

AVA's Gear Toys 1, 2, 2b and 4 have been warmly welcomed by the Thingiverse community so I thought it would be fun to create a robotic version of the classic planetary gear set. The files are printed and tested working.

It's purpose is to serve as a rotating base for learning and for simple robots. For example, as it is provided it can be a "MaracaBot" that makes sounds when spun back and forth in rhythmic fashion. Next I plan to make a feeder robot for helping disabled people.

Print "gear_planet.stl" four times; one for each bearing. Then print all other stl files only once. Assembly is straightforward.

Notes:

This is the preliminary parts list:

one NEMA 17 stepper motor

assorted M3 machine screw kit

four 608zz Skateboard bearings

one Adafruit UNO R3 board

one Adafruit motor board (requires soldering)

one 5V 1A power supply with switch

one A-B USB cable

one power switch

AVAs Gear Toy 10 can run on power from the USB cable and/or from the DC power supply.

An Acetone Vapor Chamber. This is a work in progress. I will get back to it if there is a popular response.

This is meant for glassware you can get at any hobby store, like Micheal's, Hobby Lobby, Joann's etc. The larger one is the 12" fishbowl and the other is the 8" cylinder vase. All these retail places seem to be selling the Libbey Glass company product.

The black section may be scaled as much as you want to make it as tall as you want.

The top portion fits a 100mm cutout and is the same for both sizes and the 12" bowl version will use the same base design as the 8" version. The fan vent can rotate for you to set the desired circulation pattern.

author: svivanco

description.text:
Just a few mods to this very awesome Wallet design by Pentland_Designs

  1. Redesigned hingle.
    The hinge broke to easily on the original wallet, and although the small piece of filament used as a hingle is an awesome idea, i thought it could be done with a clip together piece.
    The new hinge is also thicker and wider making it less prone to break.
    it also has a more shallow slope which makes it print far smoother if stood upright when printing (no supports)

  2. Walls were made thicker. I know its supposed to be slim, but i found the walls were too thin and would bow inwards making the mechanism less smooth. So i have thickened the walls by just 0.5mm front and back which makes the whole thing more sturdy.

  3. The cap is slightly deeper.
    The cap would not fully close of the cards in the original, so this version has a slightly deeper cap so the cap fits better over the cards.

G

As for the top, I made it slightly deeper than the original to fit over the cards better, but perhaps it's not enough for your cards. Although it is supposed to be tight so the cards hold the lid closed.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: CR-10 Z Probe with Servo Arm

description.text:
This here is a collaboration between myself and @jonathans1212

Its a Z probe designed for the CR-10 which uses a microswitch on an arm that can be moved by a servo.

Initial attemps to amount to the microswitch directly to the servo resulted in inaccurate probing. Jonathan had the idea to mount the microswitch direct to the printer frame. After doing some testing we got phenomenal results. So I thought about maybe we can use an elbow of some sort to move the arm to be stowed between probes. This is the result of that.

See the pictures as to how it all fits together. You'll need some m3 screws and nuts i'll be uploading a video on it soon.

We're getting standard deviations of like 0.001 which is insane.

The microswitch we used was the spare one that comes with the CR-10, although of course you can use the existing switch thats on the Z endstop if you wish.

A few notes about how to get this to work:

You'll need Marlin and you'll need to enable servos just like you do with the BL touch, but dont enable the BL touch, you need to enable these options:

define Z_ENDSTOP_SERVO_NR 0 // Defaults to SERVO 0 connector.

define Z_SERVO_ANGLES {60,120} // Z Servo Deploy and Stow angles

The stow angles are what ive calculated myself. You want stow to be up obviously and deploy to be down, they may vary per motor so id advise working out what they are for yours.

Offsets from extruder (if using the heavy duty customisable mount:

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -42 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]

define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 9 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]

Probe clearences ive set at:

define Z_CLEARANCE_DEPLOY_PROBE 5 // Z Clearance for Deploy/Stow

define Z_CLEARANCE_BETWEEN_PROBES 10 // Z Clearance between probe points

For maximum accuracy id advise a slower probing speed:

define Z_PROBE_SPEED_SLOW (Z_PROBE_SPEED_FAST / 4)

And id enable this so that its not constantly acting on the arm:

define DEACTIVATE_SERVOS_AFTER_MOVE

Id keep the bolts as tight as possible but obviously not too tight that the servo motor cant move the arms.

Any questions just drop a comment and ill answer. Again thanks for Jonathan for coming up with the idea and for adding a pull request to marlin that gets rid of the annoying micro jump the CR-10 does between probing.

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

I printed this at 100%, it probably doesnt need it but I wanted the arms to bed the least amount possible.
I printed this all in PETG so theres less chance of it warping over time.
I made this in 123d design using Jonathans manual mounting solution as a base

author: m56pim

print_settings.Notes:: This way prints are very massive and strong

title: UniPrint Mk I - Modular AiO Printer

description.text:
This is a first view of my own 3D Printer Project for a very Modular and upgradable printer. The UniPrint Mk I (Project Name) is in an early state yet. A special feature is it's extreme modular construction that will allow not only easy upgrades like other Motherboard, LCD or different mechanical components but also a quick-swap system that allows you to change Hot-Ends within just a minute to quickly switch between single or up to triple extruders or different nozzle sizes.

All development processes will be published here and 3D printed Parts of the Printer too. At this time I'm still on technical fine tune a lot of the parts so this will still stay a work in progress for a while. As soon as I'm able to build the first prototype, I will also publish a whole BOM list of all used parts.

Later you will be able to buy pre-assembled kits, finished printed special parts and also upgrade parts. So stay tuned!

Special Features:

  • GIANT build volume with 300x400mm Bed and 400mm Build height
  • Modular Hot-End mounts to quickly switch between different Hot-Ends types or change nozzle sizes or filament diameter
  • Planned support Hot-Ends from E3D like the V6, Cyclops, Chimera and Titan Aero for direct extrusion lovers
  • other Hot-Ends possible if desired by community in the future or just design your own mount module
  • As ultimate extruder setup, also support for RepRap Diamond (triple) Hot-End is planned
  • Easy swappable linear rails and standard sized LM12UU bearing sizes without any further disassembly
  • Massive 40x40mm aluminum frame for maximum stability and no vibrations or dislocations
  • Strong 59Ncm Nema17 Stepper Motors for core-xy mechanic, to apply maximum speed and precision control
  • Dual-Z drive for maximum stability and for easy balancing, just drive the bed all the way down to the bottom by hand
  • Premium Motherboard: RepRap Megatronics v3.1
  • Custm Marlin Firmware to switch between different configurations, depending on your used Hot-End and Extruder Setup

Also planned Features:

  • Option for Laser Engraver or Laser cut (only soft materials like plastics or wood)
  • CNC Head for simple milling jobs (also only wood and other soft materials but will check for metal like aluminum too)
  • Diamond Full Colour Hot-End (5 Colours at once? Yayyy! Need to evaluate if possible with my planned motherboard)
  • ... more to come, any suggestions?

Printer:

Customized Anet A8 e3D v6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed with PLA at 220°C for strong layer adhesion
Speed: 80mm/s with bowden
Shell: 2mm walls and also top and bottom layer

This way prints are very massive and strong

This is the manufacturing of the first prototype parts. You can see the laser cut process for the extruder-change mount plate that will become the X-carriage. For prototyping we made it of 3mm steel plates but in final version it will be 3mm aluminum to be very robust but also lower the moving mass. Finished Prototype Hot-End Mount plates. All test printed parts for now. Working at the e3D v6 Mount right now. Prototype Hot-End carriage with dummy bearings. Cable Ties will be removed with nicer solution in the future.

Update - 08.02.2018
  • Uploaded first version of the e3D v6 Mount Module
  • Updated e3D v6 Module to be more massive and robust
  • updated clamp mount holes afterwards and also nut holes because forget to do this after making body part bigger
  • Uploaded render pictures
Update - 09.02.2018

Designed a big Spool holder with ball bearings to attach up to 7 Filament spools (depending on size) to the side of the printer for easy filament change and multi-extruder use. Spools up to 220mm diameter will fit here.

Update - 12.02.2018

Changed the X-rail Holder and moved the rails up about 18mm (Updated STL). So now the X-Carriage plate is mounted below the rails. This brings more room for bigger Hot-Ends and Fan Assemblys. Also finished the Core-XY Belt mounts. Made some toothed belt mounts where belts can fit without sliding and can be completely fixed with a screw in between both belts with inserted M3 nut. Already printed and tested them and worked perfectly.

Next step is to figure out a good way to mount the plate to the bearings nicely and easy to assemble. First I thought Cable Ties would be ok but it looks like crap. You can see a Prototype Carriage on the Pictures above.

Update - 13.02.2018

Made a simple clamp for the single Linear Bearing on the back side of the X-carriage. Second Clamp for both front bearings will be made when I tested the fit of the smaller one.

author: emeraldmeadows

description.text:
After losing the baffle tube for my stick vacuum and not wanting to spend 7 dollars to wait for a new one that might not fit (due to the model being discontinued) I decided to attempt to make my own.

I have yet to actually print it in full, but my first attempts printing a short part to check the mounting measurements seem to have worked so far.
I will attempt to print the full object upside-down from how I designed it, (hense the small bridges in the locking groove) in order to need less supports.
I also made a version without the holes along the tube, because I don't quite understand why those are there (wouldn't you want the air swirling all the way down into the bottom?).

Updates after fully printing and testing the part will come (hopefully).

UPDATE: Seems to be working fine, no more dust up in the filter, and the big bits have no problem getting into the lower chamber.
It could probably stand to be a tiny bit narrower and longer at the fin end, but that shall be dealt with at a later date if I can't stand it anymore.

Measuring the mounting point was super difficult due to it being enclosed, but I basically did estimates where precision wasn't needed (like the length) and using the depth gauge of my calipers where it was.

I learned a few fun tools in Fusion 360, and learned the limits of others, but I'm still learning so... yeah.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with or without brim. Make walls, tops, and bottoms at least 1.2mm

title: Black Widow Heatsink Cooling Duct with Light and BLT Mk4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Black Widow Heatsink Cooling Duct with Light and BLT Mk4
This duct is a revision of the previous versions and has been reduced in weight. The Mk3 is pictured mounted but Mk4 stl file is available here. Will update description when I have some extra photos.

This duct is designed so that the heatsink is provided with maximum cooling even using lower powered fans. The BLTouch is mounted 45mm from the centre of the extruder so it will clear the "Evolution" series of layer coolers. This means that it will also compatible with most other types of layer coolers. Use a 40mm fan.

For best results, use a 24volt 3014 series LED as pictured. wire the LED to the same circuit as the fan, this will not only light up the extruder for you but will indicate when the hot-end is hot and the fan is on.

BLTouch offset:
32mm right
32mm forward

A spacer for the BLT has also been provided if using "Volcano" heatblock.

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

Print with or without brim. Make walls, tops, and bottoms at least 1.2mm

title: Foxeer Pagoda Pro mount for GepRC VX-5 (31mm rear standoffs)

description.text:
This is a custom mount for a Foxeer Pagoda Pro MMCX antenna intended to fit on a GepRC VX-5 mini-quadcopter frame.

Basically it will fit on the 2 35mm rear standoffs of the VX-5 frame. The distance between these standoffs is 31mm. So it can be adapted on other frames quite easily.

When installing the antenna you should use hot glue to seal it.

Intro

I designed this in order to provide a clean and robust mount for the fpv antenna. The 4 holes are intended to allow you to attach receiver antenna tubes as well using zip ties.

The one i currently use is printed with TPU filament.

29mm x 14mm x 5mm

ESC's such as the 30A Airbot Wraith Mini, and 30A Makerfire BLheli 32, fit perfectly in this cover, even when covered in a thin layer of protective heatshrink.

This ESC cover will slide over the arms and fit flush with the top of the arms, the cover also provides a spacer to keep the ESC of the carbon fiber. author: wt808

title: Automatic home plants watering system (under $10 bucks!) - Arduino Nano

description.text:
This is an under $10 home plants watering system.
It consists on measuring the humidity of soil, deciding when it´s dry enough, then turning on a water pump (a solenoid can be used if you have a hose around, I hadn’t, so I used a 5 liters “bucket”).
It´s my first time coding and using the Arduino, so don’t expect a beautiful code...
No soldering is needed. This could be a plus for some people, but made the control box a lot bigger. I’ve tried to do a smaller version, but hadn’t enough space for the wires.

Parts needed:
10 x M3 nuts
1 Arduino Nano ($2.79)
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Nano-CH340-ATmega328P-MicroUSB-Compatible-for-Arduino-Nano-V3/32572612009.html
1 Step Down power supply ($1.09)
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-1pcs-XL4005-DSN5000-Beyond-LM2596-DC-DC-adjustable-step-down-5A-power-Supply-module/32730909898.html
1 Relay module ($0.65)
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/KY-019-5V-One-1-Channel-Relay-Module-Board-Shield-For-PIC-AVR-DSP-ARM-for/32358134833.html
1 Humidity sensor module ($0.58)
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Smart-Electronics-Soil-Moisture-Hygrometer-Detection-Humidity-Sensor-Module-For-arduino-Development-Board-DIY-Robot-Smart/32562744759.html
1 Mini Protoboard ($1.98 5 pieces)
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/5PCS-SYB-170-5-Colors-Mini-Solderless-Breadboard-Prototype-Experiment-Test-Protoboard-170-Tie-Points-For/32671297865.html
1 Arduino male jumper wires ($1.00)
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/40PCS-20cm-male-to-male-2-54MM-1P-1P-Dupont-cables/32648521256.html
1 Arduino female jumper wires ($0.67)
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Dupont-line-20pcs-10cm-2-54mm-1p-1p-Pin-Female-to-Female-Color-Breadboard-Cable-Jump/32846005876.html

You will also need to print this cover for the sensor:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2474432 (I couldn’t use bolts, had to hot glue)

The last thing is find a 12v DC power supply of at least 2A. I had an old printer power supply laying around, so I used it. 2 Amps is barely the minimum. I tried a 1A but when the pump was turned on, the voltage drop was significant high to reboot the Arduino.
Optional print/buy:
Water pump support, made for mounting on a 35mm plastic “pillar”. (STL had to be fixed, I had a problem exporting in Solidworks)
This is the pump that I used:
https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-779586151-bomba-reservatorio-agua-limpador-do-parabrisa-universal-_JM
I could not find it on Aliexpress. It costed me $3.00
The pump that I used is very similar to the one below. It wont fit the STL file, but the support that I used is for a very particular case, so I think it has to be done again…
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/New-Black-Windshield-Washer-Pump-For-BMW-E46-E38-E39-E60-E65-X3-E53-X5-Z4/32807872201.html

After print everything, I had to cut the wires of the 12v power supply and use the male jump wire to connect it into the protoboard.

Then connected into the DC-DC Stepdown power supply and adjusted it to 5v. Then used the male jump wires to connect it into another line of the protoboard.
Used a male and a female jumpwire to directly power the Arduino Nano, plus the VCC of the Relay board. Do not connect the humidity sensor directly on the 5VCC, since I read that many sensors suffer from premature wear when its always powered on. I used the digital IO from the Arduino to power it.

There is an plastic “pin” on the case. This is used to fasten the pump and power supply wires with hallermann ties.

The idea is to turn on the sensor using digital IO, then measure humidity using an analog input. If the humidity is greater than 650, the soil is very dry. Another digital IO makes the Relay board give 12v to the pump. Then it compares if the humidity has changed at least 10%, and tries 20 times to make the soil reaches 400 units of humidity. If it fails, maybe the water has run out or any problem with the pump, then the programs goes into an infinite delay.

The sensor must the somewhat close to the water hose exit. I´ve used some delay to give time to the water penetrate into the soil and reach the sensor. Lower delay times between “pump and measure” gave me very wet spots. That’s why the there is almost 10 seconds between cycles.

Pump must be "submerged", so it must be placed under the water vase to be always wet.

I´ve been using this for over a month. It uses 5L of water for 1,5 week. It´s a big vase of 80x40x15 cm.

title: Inserts for Porter Cable Scroll Saw

description.text:
These are inserts for an 18-inch 1.6A Porter Cable scroll saw (PCB375SS). Unlike the insert that comes with the saw, these inserts sit flush with the top of the table. I've included three different designs; one has an L-shaped slot like the one that comes with the saw (L-Slot), one has a straight slot (Straight Slot), and one has just a 7mm hole in the center (Hole). My current favorite is the straight slot one.

These do not have the little clips on the bottom and are held in only by gravity. I haven't had an issue with this but if you want those clips, someone else made one like that (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2533523).

I printed these in PETG and they are much more rigid than the one that came with the saw because I designed them to be thicker and stronger.

remixed_from.author: Allted
remixed_from.title: Mostly Printed CNC -Part- Blank Tool Holders

description.text:
This is a mounting plate for a J-Tech laser and 40mm fan, which fits on the tool mount for the new 5/25/16 middle assembly for the MPCNC.

First bolt the laser to the mount using screws coming through the back of the plate (there are countersinks so the heads don't interfere with attaching the plate to the tool mount), then secure the plate to the MPCNC tool mount. You don't need to use all four screw holes, two is fine.

This is not a quick-release plate, screws hold it all together.

It prints upside down without supports.

author: statemind

description.text:
I've had short bits of multicore solder littering my workbench for a long long time - so I liked Kezat,'s Solder Pen, but it never printed correctly for me.
.
So - here's my fully 3D printed Solder Holder/Solder pen, for 0.8mm, 1mm & 1.6mm solder

Designed to be used flat or upright.- and won't fall off the bench if lying flat.

They hold a coil of Solder inside, which is pulled out thru the "S-bend" hole, with some slight friction to stop it falling back inside - also includes a coil winder mandrel

To wind the coil :-
1 - put in a variable speed drill - poke 40mm out the small hole in the end of the mandrel
2 - slowly wind the coil
3 - slightly loosen the solder coil and remove it from the mandrel
4 - straighten the 40mm end & insert thru the tip
5 - screw tip into body
6 - use it (OK, this last bit may be unnecessary :-)

This is an alternate rendition of the LCD dial for the Prusa i3 series. My rationale for the design was to incorporate a tactile element on the perimeter of the dial that corresponded to its rotational clicks. My count for a full revolution was 24 clicks and therefore I introduced 12 sets of grooves and lands to the dial. The design also features a wide concave top for a fully ergonomic thumb press as well as a tighter connection point on the bottom to reduce any play when activated.

comments.text: Most LEDs burn out immediatly when directly connected to more than about 3.4 Volts (red ones even with less volts!). Your torch will pass 6 Volts to the LEDs - which normally leads to direct defect of the LEDs. Maybe you were just lucky, maybe your button cells weren't quite fresh - but its not recommendable. Just my 2 cents..
comments.author: Nick_Groot

comments.text:
Interesting. I literally found these LED's (about 30 of them) so I know nothing about them. Ive been playing with several of them and had none of them burn out.
Would adding a resister to bring the voltage down be better and would that effect the output.
comments.author: Nick_Groot

comments.text:
Connecting a resistor in series with the LED is a good idea. But to determine the resistors value is far from easy maths...
There are so many different LEDs on the market and depending on their forward-voltage the correct value is not easy to find.
There is a "sweet spot" that is prolonging LED (and battery!) life significant without having a noticeable effect on the output.
I do a lot of rc hobby and still determine the best resistor value simply by testing different resistor values while checking current (mA) and evaluating output by eye-sight ;-)
if you want to dig deeper in theory, here is a ton of information:
https://www.evilmadscientist.com/2012/resistors-for-leds/
not as easy as one might think i guess... ;-)

title: tusk cooler for c/d bot multi-purpose x carriage

description.text:
This is a part inspired by SublimeLayers tusk part cooling design.

New

So, I updated this design a little bit. I'm not convinced its done - still needs more testing. the original design I was not happy with the air flow coming from the tusks. Not sure why, just was not getting enough air out. I added some additional fins to help guide some of the air while still forcing out the tusks. For sure you need the sock as this is sadly blowing right at the heater - I need to make a tweak to force it downward but I'm thinking a different design entirely ( from the side this time instead of the back )

Very curious to hear how this works for you if you put it to use. I mount the extruder left side 1 row up from my mount plate - gives more Z height that way.

Any future iterations will likely go to a new thing design and I'll make a link from here.

Oh, use the slicer app to flip the parts upside down ;) Forgot to do that on the export - its pretty simple in the slicer anyway

Original

This goes along with my recent designs. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2762077 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2764868.

The height is adjustable. I believe it will work with a volcano however I have not verified.

What you will need to mount to the plate:

  1. 6 m3 6mm ( 2 for the back plate, 4 for the side )
  2. 2 x m2.5 5mm for the fan
  3. 1 x 30x30x10 mm blower fan
    • I plan to make a version of this plate for other blower fans in the future
  4. K&S 5/16" brass tubing or 4mm if you can find it
    • I got mine at a local hobby store, 3 sticks for $5-6
  5. 4mm drill bit ( and/or 4.2mm )
  6. 2.5mm drill bit
  7. TuskDrillJig from thing:2445660
  8. pipe cutter, I used a rigid close quarters - just be careful as the pipe is really thin and technically that is only for > 5mm

Once printed, measure out 2 ~85mm lengths. Drill out the TuskDrillJig with M4 and M2.5 ( I used 4.2 for the pipe, was too tight )

I attached the f360 export, feel free to make changes / tweaks. If you end up printing/using I'd love to hear some feedback ;)

I'm a little unsure of the air flow with this design. I'm used to pushing a lot more air onto the part but this is much more focused so maybe its not a big deal?

print_settings.Notes:: Enabling supports helped improve bracket mounting hole shape and size.

description.text:
Here's yet another approach to mounting the Tronxy X5S Control Panel at a more convenient and visible angle. This scheme mounts the standard control panel onto "tilted supports" that are then mounted to the printer frame with T-nuts. Three (3) #4 x 1/2 inch self-taping sheet metal screws are used to attached the control panel to the panel supports.

The printed supports are a 'minimalist' design that are quickly printed (<10 min ea) and use very little material. The 'odd rib pattern' allows the support members to 'dodge around' the control panel circuit boards and their mounts.

I used PLA to make these parts. Despite the open rib design, the mount is very rigid once all parts are fully assembled and mounted to the Tronxy frame.

author: gregland

description.text: Motor mount for relocating the Y belt on ShapeOko outside the frame.

Two options for motor mount, to relocate the belt outside the frame. This increases the usable area, and prevents the Z carriage colliding with bearings.

  • Clean out the 3mm holes so M3 bolts fit snugly. For the M5 holes, you can tap them with the same tool you used on aluminium MakerSlide, or clean them as per M3.

  • Refit the idler bearings to the outside, using spare holes near the bottom corners as pictured.
    • Mount A
  • Attach motor to mount with 2x M3 screws with washers
  • Use two M3 x 30mm screws through washers, plate, mount, into motor. These screws might not be easy to source; if it's a problem, use mount M below.
  • Use two M5 screws to secure the bottom.
    • Mount M
  • Attach motor to mount with 4x M3 screws with washers.
  • Attach mount to plate with 4x M5 screws.
    • My ShapeOko isn't running yet, so I haven't proven it under load. However, it should be more robust than simply mounting the motor out on spacers.

title: Cats Vs Dogs Board Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cats vs Dogs by Chris Hansen - For years cats and dogs have feuded over who was the greatest pet in the neighborhood. Today they have decided to settle the argument once and for all with an epic battle in the streets!

Cats vs Dogs is a two-player game. One player will control the cats and the other the dogs. Your goal is to take control of the yard friendly to your opponent – or scare them off the board. But be careful, the board is littered with distractions that will make your animals lose focus during the heat of battle. Can you lead your animals to victory?

Each player gets 10 pieces which are set up hidden from the opponent. Players move on a grid showing several houses and a street from the neighborhood. When two pieces occupy the same square, both players will reveal their piece and play a card adding to its value. The player with the highest total will win the battle. However, if you're fighting in a square with a distraction, you total battle strength will be reduced.

The winner is the player who can occupy his opponent's yard on the far side of the board. This is a lighthearted game that plays quickly and is simple enough for young children but with enough strategy to keep their parents entertained as well.

title: Quadcopter motor mount and parts for 1/2 x 1/2 square dowel from Home Depot or Lowes.

description.text:
This motor mount was printed in PLA with 4 shells and 15% infill on a Makerbot Replicator at Techshop Chandler. I used Autodesk Inventor to design the 3d file.  
The main frame is 1/2" square dowels and the landing gear are 3/8" square dowels on the motor mount or you can use the T fitting to make tougher landing gear for heavier multicopters.  
The motor mounting bolt spacing will fit motors with anywhere from 20x20 mm mounting bolt pattern. I use motors with 16x19 mm bolt spacing. The motor mounts take about an hour to print with ,2mm standard definition.

This motor mount was printed in PLA with 4 shells and 15% infill on a Makerbot Replicator at Techshop Chandler. The main frame is 1/2 and the landing gear are 3/8" square dowels.   
The middle of my quadcopters shown here are from www.flighttest.com which they have available on thier website forum. Or you could design your own.  
The motor mount  has gone through some revisions. I had to beef up the landing gear so they wouldn't keep breaking off but the file now prints out a little artifact line where the area was beefed up. Hardly noticeable though.

description.text:
Good morning, this really isn't a part but more of a demonstration and idea to give everyone some inspiration to go out and make some awesome light diffusers and such. This light diffuser I created was originally supposed to be a tealight holder... But I figured that it would be better to release it this way instead. I expected it to give a pixellated look, and it did. The filament I used is supposed to be see thru, but it didn't come out that clear. I will need to change some settings to make it work. I included the Fusion 360 file as well so people can see how it is made so they can make it themselves as well.

FYI, I used t-gaus filament. You really want translucent filament when doing this. The more see-thru the better. It's even more see-thru if you coat it with XTC-3D.

description.text: Hello printers! Today I bring you the Jeep Logo Key Fob! If you own a Jeep, and want that Jeep logo on your keys for your truck, then 3D print this! I was amazed that I couldn't find anything like this for a key chain! That's why I made one! I would recommend having a dual extruder on your 3D Printer. Having a dual extruder will allow you to print this logo in the original Jeep logo colour scheme. If you do not own a dual extruder printer, then print it in black, and paint the very top white. It's all up to you. Also, supports are recommended.

description.header: Supports... Do I Need Them For This Print?
description.text:
Should I use supports while printing this?

YES! YOU DO NEED SUPPORTS! The reason why you need supports is because there's a cylinder going through the logo to keep it together/connected without it breaking. So, yes! Use supports!

What are these previews for?

They lets you see what the final product will be when in color. I don't have a printer, but know a thing or two about 3D modeling and printing. That's why I only create, but not for long!

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Extruder/Hotend Assembly with mk10 Drive for Tronxy

description.text:
I got tired of the bowden extruder on my Tronxy X3S. After recently buying an original prusa i3 mk2s and falling in love with it, I decided I wanted to add a the prusa style hotend/extruder assembly to my tronxy. I stumbled upon 3DPropWorx's remix of the prusa i3 mk2 extruder and thought it was perfect for what I wanted to do. Plus I figured I could get away with not having to purchase anything to do the conversion as I already had an e3d v6. So besides that, I just needed to modify it to fit to the tronxy and to accept some of the tronxy parts such as the extruder gear and idler.

It's designed to bolt to the original tronxy x carriage plate from the back side using M3x8mm screws through the holes where the original hot end stand offs go (you'll have to drill holes for this, however, I may add these holes to the model in the future). You will also need to fully assemble this before you mount it to the x carriage plate.

I didn't take note of the number or size of screws and bolts used, but I can probably go back to catalog that information if there is a demand for it. For the most part you end up using the screws/nuts from the original prusa assembly guide. Just be sure to measure lengths.

print_settings.Notes:: The nesting sections were specifically designed to be mostly hollow with 3mm wall thickness where needed which prints solid without the need for the printer to create any infill.  This makes them very strong without wasting filament!

description.text:
Features:

  • Stackable design for easy setup/teardown and printer access
  • (8) Clear Acrylic panels create two enclosed areas for temperature control or enclosed storage
  • Panels are held on with neodymium magnets for easy removal
  • Efficient design is strong yet hollow to save filament
  • Designed to allow each section to be lifted off without having to remove acrylic panels

This is my take on the Ikea Lack Printer enclosure. It is not the first design on Thingiverse and it certainly won't be the last. This version boasts a modular design that lets you easily stack your tables and dismantle with ease. The stackable design also means you can quickly and easily remove the top cover for easy access to your printer. The 8 removable acrylic panels are held on with neodymium magnets for easy removal while also providing a closed in area for better temperature control when printing plastics like ABS. My design also allows the acrylic panels to remain in place while lifting off the sections which further simplifies the setup and take down of this enclosure.

When first searching for a printer enclosure for my new Prusa i3 MK2S, I found the brilliant design by LKM (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1843235) which uses super cheap Ikea Lack tables for the main structure. It also used 3D printed parts to extend the legs and provide mounts for clear plastic sides to attach and enclose the printing area. I also found thebeetleuk's clever design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2212749) which allowed the tables to be easily and securely stacked but also removable for easy access to the printer.

Like I do with some of my designs, I started with these two ideas and simply made some tweaks and modifications to make them my own.

Mainly, I wanted the acrylic sheets to sit nicely inside the table legs to give more of a picture frame appearance while still maximizing the interior space as much as possible. I designed my own magnetic mounts to use standard magnets found at Home Depot. These mounts have small, built in handles to allow you to easily grip and remove a panel if needed. Then I hollowed out the nesting leg pieces and optimized the wall thickness to be both solid and strong without the need for printer generated infill. Since I designed most of the interior as open, the biggest benefit was not wasting unneeded plastic to fill in these areas.

To finish it off, I of course found lots of great accessories here on Thingiverse such as:
The spool holder - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:943563
The filament guide - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2114888
The feet - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2076126
and the cable grommet - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2225786

I also sourced some cheap RGBW LED strips (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01HD37U6S/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1) to light the build area. I put three 400mm strips of these above the build area and then two 400mm strips down the front legs. To mount these on the legs, I designed some 45 degree mounting strips which snap together in section lengths designed to match the LED pitch of my 60 LED/m strips. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2782466

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I tried my hardest to design these parts without the need for supports but in the end, I feel you must use supports anyway if you want to get the most accurate parts. Basically, any piece that has the large magnetic mount should be printed with supports for the best fit.

The nesting sections were specifically designed to be mostly hollow with 3mm wall thickness where needed which prints solid without the need for the printer to create any infill. This makes them very strong without wasting filament!

Top Spacer printed with supports. Mounting tabs can be batch printed with no supports required.

These are designed to slip snugly over 0.093 Acrylic panels. I was planning to super glue the tabs to the panels but they seem to friction fit just fine without glue.

Included drill template ensures perfect fit

Slide this template over the bottom of each leg and it will allow you to drill perfectly aligned holes for the leg extensions. Take the same template and hook it over the Ikea Lack table top and it will allow you to drill perfectly aligned holes for the socket pieces.

This way when you start stacking your tables they will nest perfectly and be completely aligned.

Socket mounted to table top using wood screws into previously drilled pilot holes. Socket pieces batch printed without supports

No wasted filament here! The 3mm wall thickness gives plenty of strength and means no printer infill. Lots of hollow air space means no wasted filament!

Magnets purchased from Home Depot

These small neodymium magnets are plenty powerful enough to hold the panels up. Take extra care making sure you glue all magnets in with the correct polarity!

Close-up of how everything fits together

You can use a strip of foam tape or weather seal to fill the air gap around windows for better temperature controlled printing.
Fusion 360

description.text:
This is a support structure to prevent accidental activations of the large PTT button on the Sena SR10. This 3d-printed supportive shell is hard-mounted to the unit using four M3x8 machine screws.

Why?
The Sena SR10 allows a user to have an externally-mounted, remote push-to-talk (PTT) switch. This is nice because it allows you to easily throw the SR10 into a pocket, bag, or pouch during transport. However, the external PTT does not disable the larger, on-unit PTT button. Because the on-unit button is so large, it can be accidentally depressed when in a pocket or bag - resulting in an unwanted open broadcast channel. This box creates a shell around the SR10 to help prevent accidental presses of the on-unit PTT button by recessing it below the 3d-printed surface.

Assembly

  1. Align the enclosure openings with SR10's USB and external PTT ports
  2. Slide the Sena SR10 into the 3d-printed enclosure
  3. Secure the enclosure to the rear of the SR10 with four M3x8 machine screws.

description.text: A simple wall mounted strap to organize and secure 4 inch hose.

This bit holder is designed to be as low profile as possible. It holds 2 bits. The bits are held in by friction, but there are also little detent bumps within the holder.

There is a tongue on the holder that goes into the little 1" long slot (similar to how the standard belt clip attaches). That makes it very secure, but it also means the holder will only fit on the right hand side of the drill/driver. If you want it on the left, print a mirrored version (or I suppose you could drill another hole in the right spot)

I printed this on an Anet A8, using PLA. It took me a few tries to get the fit right, so the bits are held securely but not so tight that they're impossible to get back out. If you have trouble, the fit can be adjusted by scaling the print slightly or just by using sandpaper.

Print it standing on end with the hole farthest from the build plate. I use a 0.4mm nozzle, and designed the part with wall thicknesses that are multiples of the nozzle diameter for smoother, faster printing. I use a heated glass build plate, with a starting temperature of 65C and starting extruder temp of 210C. The temps drop to 60 and 200 after the first layer.

Use an M4 screw to attach it.
A simple clamp to secure 4" hose. Designed to be used with M3 hardware.

My 1403 Printrbot Simple Metal kit came with bearing blocks that require LME12UU bushings. Hard to find drylin, and even harder to find a quality bearing in this size, a printed alternative works great here. I used a diamond file to sand the sliding surface to a smooth finish.
Adjustable endstop switch mount for an 8mm rod. Used on my knock-off Prusa i3

title: MyRCCar Central Differential Housing for HSP02024 Diff conversion, SST09304 and other 1/8 diffs.

description.text:
Hi there!

One more time, the third thing in a row... the quality of presentations goes decreasing but things are things, and mines need to be free!!!

This time it's about the central differential housing for your rc car. When you start thinking what you need, sometimes you discover something new, like those special bearings for the central diff or an adaptor for the motor pinion shaft...

The whole proyect is trying to reduce the need of this "5 bucks" things at minimum, but for sure you wont get the same durability than with metal ones.

So if you want to spend some extra in a center differential this could be the housing for you. Most 1/10 cars dont use central diff so most you will find will be 1/8 scale.

Anyway i provide here a converter for an HSP 02024 diff to make it be a Mod1 46T diff. It consists in two parts wich enclose the 02024 diff gear. Will you give it a try?¿?¿?

The inspiration for this came from NiKO2On and his thing

This time is easy. You have to print the bottom and the top of the box, then print your appropriate adapters to your diff. If you want to use de 02024 as a central diff. print the two converter parts. If you dont want to spend 10$ in a pinion and an adaptor, print the provided Mod1 14T pinion (made for the trooper diff), or make your own motor pinion with my Motor Pinion Generator.

Please don't forget this is part of the MyRCCar proyect so it will fit in MyRCCar Universal Chassis. Also please join the MyRCCar Group to help improving MyRCCar, YourRCCar i hope soon ;)

title: Fast Release Earbud Wrap Designer v2.2

description.text:
This earbud holder features:

  • Convenient flat storage when not in use
  • Business card size, credit card size, and custom sizes
  • Quick wrapping action
  • Even quicker release feature. The last loop with the audio jack holds the other loops in place. Release it, and you can release all the other loops instantly.
  • Customizable location of notch for windings relative to earbud holes
  • Customizable width of slots for the cord
  • Customizable size of earbud holes
  • Customizable corner rounding. Make the corners square, even.
  • Optional central holes so you can thread the cord through them to keep it handy while you are listening
  • Optional notch for the slide-off side of the winding
  • Optional sloped notch for the slide-off side
  • Optional tab at the end of the slide-off notch to, ironically, keep the cord from sliding off while wrapping.
  • Optional jack notches on the opposite side of the card for more winding options
  • Optional engraved text
  • Optional additional winding notches
  • Improved cord notches to hold the jack

If Thingiverse's Customizer is working, this is your best bet for customizing. If not,

  • Install the Development version of OpenSCAD (http://www.openscad.org/downloads.html#snapshots)
  • Enable the Customizer according to https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/WIP#Customizer
  • Open the .scad file
  • Set your customizations
  • Render
  • Export as an STL file

Not much in presets yet. The Default matches DavidPhillipOster's thing that I mixed from. If you find settings that work well for a recognizable pair of earbuds, let me know and I'll add them to the presets.

Want a feature added? Let me know.

Release Notes
Version 2.1

  • Changed jack notch to "T" shape in the middle and flipped at the top.
  • Added optional jack notches to opposite side to take up extra cord length.
  • Added optional slope to winding side for easier removal.
  • Reorganized customizations.

Version 2.2

  • Optional engraved text.

Version 2.3
// Adjusted OnePlus presets: larger slots (from 3.3 to 3.5)
// New extra feature: Added a tab to the slide notch
// New extra feature: Added minor winding notches.
// Moved slide notch to Extras

Version 2.4
// Adjusted OnePlus presets:
//// Increase slot_width to 3.7 for OnePlus
//// Decrease earbud radius substantially
// Smaller tab on slide notch
// Minor winding slots are deeper and not added if there's not room
// Bugfix: only printing half a card

Printer:

Monoprice Mini select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm high x 0.4mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

It's an easy print with PLA.

Remix, OpenSCAD and Customizer

Started with Earbud-Wrap with Fast Release by DavidPhillipOster (itself a remix from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8528), added some features suggested by my son, and made it all Customizer friendly.

Owe a debt to Splines for OpenSCAD by teejaydub as well.
